statement:
If the orders of two subgroups of a group are , the identity element is
the only common element of the subgroups.\
*Proof.* Let $G$ and $H$ be such subgroups and $|G|$ and $|H|$ their
orders. Then the intersection $G\!\cap\!H$ is a subgroup of both $G$ and
$H$. By Lagrange’s theorem, $|G\!\cap\!H|$ divides both $|G|$ and $|H|$
and consequently it divides also $\gcd(|G|,\,|H|)$ which is 1. Therefore
$|G\!\cap\!H| = 1$, whence the intersection contains only the identity
element.\
**Example.** All subgroups
$$\{(1),\,(12)\},\quad \{(1),\,(13)\}, \quad \{(1),\,(23)\}$$ of order 2
of the symmetric group $\mathfrak{S}_3$ have only the identity element
$(1)$ common with the sole subgroup $$\{(1),\,(123),\,(132)\}$$ of order
3.
